Award.AwardTitle: EDUCERE: Ensuring Diversity and Undergraduate Completion: Enrichment and Retention In Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Northern New Mexico College serves a 77% underrepresented minority and underprepared population with high attrition rates in the first two years. The College of Engineering and Technology is developing a research-generated knowledge base of how this student demographic best learns complex foundational Physical Science concepts by using the evidence-based Wright State model to create an introductory Physics course with project based activities that students will take prior to a theory-based Physics course. Students are being tracked to determine if this intervention leads to increases in learning, ability to apply concepts, and retention. Additionally, Native American and Hispanic students with high degrees of interdependent self-construal are being studied to determine if they respond better to active learning prior to theoretical learning.

The investigators will use a matched subjects samples methodology and a modification of the Solomon four-group research design. In addition, undergraduate research experiences are being studied to determine if they foster retention and greater clarity on future career pathways among these unique populations. The project expects to generate new scientific knowledge of effective interventions leading to retention in engineering among students from rural and tightly knit communities. For example, advances in understanding of how under-prepared populations best learn; contributions to education research regarding effective practices in engineering teaching and learning among understudied groups; and discoveries on successful strategies that can broaden participation of Native Americans, Hispanics and women in engineering programs. The proposed work is likely to produce a model that can be disseminated to other institutions facing similar challenges, or those that are focusing on diversifying engineering undergraduate population in their programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Ensuring Diversity and Undergraduate Completion: Enrichment and Retention in Engineering" (EDUCERE) project has been implemented at Northern New Mexico College (NNMC) during the period Fall 2016 to Fall 2020. The main goals of the project include: 1) Improve Engineering Learning and Learning Environments: Improve the knowledge base for defining, identifying, and innovating effective undergraduate engineering education using evidence-based resources and pedagogies in undergraduate (Electromechanical Engineering Technology) EMET education; 2) Broaden Participation for Engineering Learning: Increase the number of students recruited and retained in the EMET program; and 3) Build the Professional Engineering Workforce for Tomorrow: Improve the preparation of undergraduates so they succeed as productive members of the future engineering workforce and be engaged in STEM-literate society.

Throughout the project period, project personnel re-envisioned, redesigned the teaching and curricula, as well as the sequence for the crucial Engineering Math and Physics courses. Five different courses were redesigned to employ hands-on, engineering-contextualized, active learning methods to foster better engagement and learning among our unique underrepresented minority (URM; 77%, approximately 72% Hispanics) and academically underprepared students (approximately 83%). We have built and enhanced our laboratory facilities (including a grant-funded subsonic wind-tunnel, and several other Physics equipment), and incorporated them in our freshman Math and Physics courses. A total of 124 different students (including the EMET program and our other engineering technology program in Information Technology) were impacted so far with the new curricula and laboratory facilities. A total of 11 students (9 funded by the project) were trained in tutoring and mentoring, who served as peer-tutors in these classes and helped reshape the learning community.

These initiatives resulted in the following significant outcomes: First, the retention rates among cohorts in the Engineering Math and Physics classes (Fall 2016- Fall 2019) have been significantly higher (80-100% from first to second semester, 62-88% in the third semester, and 57-79% in the fourth semester; as compared to NNMC′s general student retention rates of 78%, 66%, and 50% in the second, third and fourth semesters, respectively). Secondly, the recruitment and retention efforts helped to grow the enrollment numbers from 23 in Fall 2015 (prior to the inception of the project) to 35 in Fall 2019, an increase by 52% (target was 45%). Finally, we see a significantly higher persistence and eventually graduation rate following the inception of the project in 2016. The number of graduates per year have increased by a factor of 3 or 4 (comparing the total number of graduates on or before 2016 with the recent graduates in 2018-2020).

EDUCERE project provided faculty-mentored research opportunities to nine different students (five engineering students and four social-science students). Also, six different students were provided with summer internship opportunities at the nearby Los Alamos National Lab, and other technical companies, and gained valuable on-the-job training. Several of these students were engaged in research or internships for multiple semesters. Among the 18 graduates so far from the Bachelor in EMET program, 13 students were involved either in tutoring/mentoring, academic research or external internships. All of the graduates were impacted by the project, either through research/tutoring and mentoring training/internships, or they had been part of the new cohorts who went through the new Math and Physics curricula. Out of these 18 graduates from the EMET program, at least 78% are currently working in a technical job in STEM field, or in STEM education (most of them started working in these jobs even before graduation). At least 17% of these graduates have completed or currently pursuing graduate studies (including one graduate who had completed her Masters′ degree in Mechanical Engineering).

The project results were disseminated in the form of a conference paper, and a poster presentation at the 2019 American Society of Engineering Education Annual Conference in Tampa, Florida. Also, a total of five student researchers (4 from engineering and 1 from social sciences) have disseminated their research findings through poster presentation in the NNMC annual research symposium. Two engineering student′s aerodynamics research work with the grant-funded wind-tunnel were presented as a poster in the 2019 Annual Alliance for Minority Participation conference, at the New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, New Mexico. The project personnel have also gained valuable professional development training in the field of engineering education through five different conferences or workshops.

Finally, the project assisted in shaping up the new EMET program through redesign of curricula, enhanced laboratory facilities, increased student support and engagement, graduation, and better preparation for the future workforce. The project helped significantly in securing the full accreditation of the Bachelor of Engineering in EMET program by the highest accreditation agency for Engineering and Technology, namely ABET (Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology).
